rev.comment: /* Countries where protests have taken place */ Alphabetical order
rev.diff:
Line 69: Line 69:
==Countries where protests have taken place==
==Countries where protests have taken place==
â   â
===Tunisia===
  â
[[File:Tunisia Unrest - VOA - Tunis 14 Jan 2011 (2).jpg|thumb|Demonstrators in downtown [[Tunis]] on January 14th, 2011]]
  â
{{main|2010â2011 Tunisian uprising}}
  â
The 2010â2011 Tunisian uprising is a continuing series of street demonstrations taking place throughout Tunisia from December 2010 onwards. The demonstrations and riots were reported to have started over unemployment, food inflation, corruption, freedom of speech and poor living conditions. The protests were exacerbated by the self-immolation of [[Mohamed Bouazizi]] that eventually led to the ousting of President Zine El Abidine Ben Ali, who stepped down from the presidency and fled Tunisia on 14 January 2011 after 23 years in power.
 
===Algeria===
===Algeria===
Line 88: Line 83:
On 3 February, President [[Abdelaziz Bouteflika]] announced that the 19-year state of emergency would be lifted in the very near future in an apparent bid to stave off unrest.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/02/20112315364175524.html|title=Algeria to lift emergency powers}}</ref>
On 3 February, President [[Abdelaziz Bouteflika]] announced that the 19-year state of emergency would be lifted in the very near future in an apparent bid to stave off unrest.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/02/20112315364175524.html|title=Algeria to lift emergency powers}}</ref>
â
===Libya===
+
===Bahrain===
â
From 13â16 January, upset at delays and corruption, protesters in Darnah, Benghazi, Bani Walid and other cities in Libya broke into and occupied housing that the government was building.<ref>{{cite web | title = Libyans protest over delayed subsidized housing units | url = http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/libyans-protest-over-delayed-subsidized-housing-units | date = 2011-01-16 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title = Libya protest over housing enters its third day | url = http://www.mesop.de/2011/01/16/libya-protest-over-housing-enters-its-third-day/ | author = Mohamed Abdel-Baky | date = 2011-01-16 }}</ref> By 27 January the government had responded to the unrest with a $24 billion investment fund to provide housing and development.<ref name=Libya1/>
+
''Al Jazeera'' reported planned protests in the country{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}}, which follow just months on from a controversial [[Bahraini parliamentary election, 2010|election]]. On 4 February, several hundred Bahrainis gathered in front of the Egyptian embassy in [[Manama]] to express solidarity with anti-government protesters in Egypt.<ref name="WSJ_bahrain_20110204">{{cite news | first= Nour | last= Malas |coauthors= Hassan Hafidh, Joel Millman | pages= | language =| title=Protests Emerge in Jordan, Bahrain | date=2011-02-05 | publisher=Wall Street Journal | url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748704709304576124623383327338.html |accessdate=2011-02-06 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wKLMmSyY |archivedate=2011-02-07 |deadurl=no }}</ref> According to the ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', this was "one of the first such gatherings to be held in the oil-rich Persian Gulf states."<ref name="WSJ_bahrain_20110204" /> At the gathering, [[Ibrahim Sharif]], the secretary-general of the [[National Democratic Action Society]], (al-Wa'ad) called for "local reform."<ref name="WSJ_bahrain_20110204" />
â
In late January, Jamal al-Hajji, a Libyan writer, political commentator and accountant, "call[ed] on the internet for demonstrations to be held in support of greater freedoms in Libya" following the Tunisian and Egyptian uprisings.<ref name="AI_JamalH">{{cite web| last =| first =| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =Libyan writer detained following protest call| work =| publisher =[[Amnesty International]]| date =2011-02-08| url =http://www.amnesty.org/en/news-and-updates/libyan-writer-detained-following-protest-call-2011-02-08 |format =| doi =| accessdate =2011-02-08 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wLwGDmVM |archivedate=2011-02-08 |deadurl=no }}</ref> He was arrested on 1 February by plain-clothes police officers and charged on 3 February with injurying someone with his car. [[Amnesty International]] stated that al-Hajji had previously been imprisoned for his non-violent political opinions and that the real reason for the present arrest appeared to be his call for demonstrations.<ref name="AI_JamalH" />
+
Bahraini youth also called for Bahrainis "to take to the streets on Monday 14 February in a peaceful and orderly manner" in order to rewrite the [[Constitution of Bahrain|constitution]] and to establish a body with a "full popular mandate to investigate and hold to account [[human rights in Bahrain|economic, political and social violations]], including stolen public wealth, political naturalisation, arrests, [[torture in Bahrain|torture]] and other oppressive security measures, [and] institutional and economic corruption."<ref name="bahrainonline_20110214">{{cite web| last =| first =| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =A statement by Bahraini Youth for Freedom published on BahrainOnline | work =| publisher =BahrainOnline| date =2011| url =http://bahrainonline.info.tm/ |format =| doi =| accessdate =2011-02-07 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wKQYGf0Q |archivedate=2011-02-07 |deadurl=no }}</ref><ref name="aljaz_febdominos" /> They referred to the uprisings in Tunisia and Egypt as motivations for their appeal.<ref name="bahrainonline_20110214" />
â
''[[Al Jazeera]]'' stated that protests are planned for 17 February.<ref name="aljaz_febdominos">{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Calls for weekend protests in Syria | date=2011-02-04 | publisher=[[Al Jazeera]] | url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201122171649677912.html |accessdate=2011-02-08 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wLygnerq |archivedate=2011-02-08 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
+
===Djibouti===
  +
Three-hundred people protested against President [[Ismail Omar Guelleh]] in [[Djibouti (city)|Djibouti]] asking him not to run for another term and also for more liberty and for political and social reform. ''[[Somalilandpress]]'' described the protests as peaceful.<ref>{{cite news|title=People in Djibouti protest against President Gelleh|author=|newspaper=Somalilandpress|date=|url=http://somalilandpress.com/people-in-djibouti-protest-againts-president-gelleh-19925|accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref>
  +   +
===Egypt===
  +
{{Incomplete|date=February 2011}}<!--need roots of conflict instead of extraneous details like the stock market-->
  +
[[File:Day of Anger marchers with out signs.jpg|thumb|Protesters marching on 25 January. Demonstrators later moved to [[Midan Tahrir|al-Tahrir Square]], in [[Downtown Cairo]], where the main protests were being held.]]
  +
{{main|2011 Egyptian protests}}
  +   +
Following the [[Death of Khaled Mohamed Saeed|death of Khaled Saeed]] in June of 2010, and the later uprising in Tunisia, potential [[Egyptian presidential election, 2011|presidential candidate]] [[Mohamed ElBaradei]] warned of a "Tunisia-style explosion" in the country.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theage.com.au/world/warning-egypt-could-follow-tunisia-20110119-19wly.html|title=Warning Egypt could follow Tunisia|author=Jack Shenker}}</ref>
  +   +
Starting at about 00:10 to 00:35 on 28 January (Egypt time), in an unprecedented action in the history of [[Internet censorship]], the Egyptian government almost entirely cut off Egypt from the rest of the Internet.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pomed.org/blog/2011/01/egypt-ap-confirms-government-has-disrupted-internet-service.html/ |title=Egypt: AP Confirms Government has Disrupted Internet Service |publisher=pomed.org |date= |accessdate=2011-01-28}}</ref>
  +   +
Later that day, as tens of thousand protested on the streets of Egypt's major cities, President Mubarak formally fired his government, and appointed a new one, which included the first Vice President in almost 30 years.
  +   +
However, this did not mollify anyone, and over the next few days the crowds grew, with some estimates in the hundreds of thousands. According to Al Jazeera on 1 February at least one million protesters gathered on Tahrir Square and adjacent streets.<ref>{{cite web |publisher=Al Jazeera News|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/2011215827193882.html|title=Protesters flood Egypt streets|date=1 February 2011|accessdate=2011-01-31}}</ref> President Mubarak subsequently proclaimed that he will not contend for another presidential term.
  +   +
Beginning on 2 February, armed men on camels and horses began to attack protesters with [[Molotov cocktails]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20110202/ap_on_re_mi_ea/ml_egypt |title=Mubarak backers attack anti-government protesters - Yahoo! News |publisher=News.yahoo.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-02}}</ref>
  +   +
The same organisers of the "Day of Anger" and "Friday of Anger" called for a protest in front of the presidential [[Heliopolis Palace]] on 4 February, which was dubbed the "'''Friday of Departure'''".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/163162.html|title=4 Feb. Declared the 'Friday of Departure'|author=|date=2 February 2011|work=[[Press TV]]|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> ({{lang-ar|Ø¬ÙØ¹Ø© Ø§ÙØ±Ø­ÙÙ}} ''{{transl|ar|DIN|gumÊ¿at ar-raá¸¥Ä«l}}'')<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alraimedia.com/Alrai/Article.aspx?id=253982&date=02022011|title=Ø¬ÙØ¹Ø© Ø§ÙØ±Ø­ÙÙ|language=[[Arabic language|Arabic]]|author=|date=2 February 2011|work=[[Al Rai]]|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> They demanded Mubarak step down immediately, with 4 February their deadline for him to surrender his powers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Egypt-Protests-What-Will-Be-The-Future-For-President-Mubarak/Article/201102115920698?lpos=World_News_First_World_News_Article_Teaser_Region_4&lid=ARTICLE_15920698_Egypt_Protests%3A_What_Will_Be_The_Future_For_President_Mubarak|title=What Is the Future for President Mubarak?|author=|date=2 February 2011|work=[[Sky News]]|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
===Jordan===
===Jordan===
Line 111: Line 106:
| date= 1 February 2011
| date= 1 February 2011
| accessdate= 1 February 2011}}</ref> King Abdullah told Bakhit his authority will be to "take quick, concrete and practical steps to launch a genuine political reform process". The reforms should put Jordan on the path "to strengthen democracy," and provide Jordanians with the "dignified life they deserve," the monarch said.<ref>{{cite web|last=Derhally |first=Massoud A |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-01/jordan-s-prime-minister-rifai-resigns-king-asks-bakhit-to-form-government.html |title=Jordan's King Abdullah Replaces Prime Minister |publisher=Bloomberg.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref>
| accessdate= 1 February 2011}}</ref> King Abdullah told Bakhit his authority will be to "take quick, concrete and practical steps to launch a genuine political reform process". The reforms should put Jordan on the path "to strengthen democracy," and provide Jordanians with the "dignified life they deserve," the monarch said.<ref>{{cite web|last=Derhally |first=Massoud A |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-01/jordan-s-prime-minister-rifai-resigns-king-asks-bakhit-to-form-government.html |title=Jordan's King Abdullah Replaces Prime Minister |publisher=Bloomberg.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-01}}</ref>
  +   +
===Libya===
  +
From 13â16 January, upset at delays and corruption, protesters in Darnah, Benghazi, Bani Walid and other cities in Libya broke into and occupied housing that the government was building.<ref>{{cite web | title = Libyans protest over delayed subsidized housing units | url = http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/libyans-protest-over-delayed-subsidized-housing-units | date = 2011-01-16 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title = Libya protest over housing enters its third day | url = http://www.mesop.de/2011/01/16/libya-protest-over-housing-enters-its-third-day/ | author = Mohamed Abdel-Baky | date = 2011-01-16 }}</ref> By 27 January the government had responded to the unrest with a $24 billion investment fund to provide housing and development.<ref name=Libya1/>
  +   +
In late January, Jamal al-Hajji, a Libyan writer, political commentator and accountant, "call[ed] on the internet for demonstrations to be held in support of greater freedoms in Libya" following the Tunisian and Egyptian uprisings.<ref name="AI_JamalH">{{cite web| last =| first =| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =Libyan writer detained following protest call| work =| publisher =[[Amnesty International]]| date =2011-02-08| url =http://www.amnesty.org/en/news-and-updates/libyan-writer-detained-following-protest-call-2011-02-08 |format =| doi =| accessdate =2011-02-08 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wLwGDmVM |archivedate=2011-02-08 |deadurl=no }}</ref> He was arrested on 1 February by plain-clothes police officers and charged on 3 February with injurying someone with his car. [[Amnesty International]] stated that al-Hajji had previously been imprisoned for his non-violent political opinions and that the real reason for the present arrest appeared to be his call for demonstrations.<ref name="AI_JamalH" />
  +   +
''[[Al Jazeera]]'' stated that protests are planned for 17 February.<ref name="aljaz_febdominos">{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Calls for weekend protests in Syria | date=2011-02-04 | publisher=[[Al Jazeera]] | url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201122171649677912.html |accessdate=2011-02-08 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wLygnerq |archivedate=2011-02-08 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
===Mauritania===
===Mauritania===
There were also similar protests in [[Mauritania]] where Yacoub Ould Dahoud, a protester, [[Self-immolation|burned himself]] near the Presidential Palace in opposition to the policies of [[Mohamed Ould Abdel Aziz]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wikiwix.com/cache/?url=http://www.leparisien.fr/flash-actualite-monde/mauritanie-mecontent-du-regime-un-homme-s-immole-par-le-feu-a-nouakchott-17-01-2011-1231257.php&title=%5B2%5D |title=Wikiwix's cache |publisher=Wikiwix.com |date=2011-01-17 |accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref><!--Is that RS?--><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leparisien.fr/flash-actualite-monde/mauritanie-mecontent-du-regime-un-homme-s-immole-par-le-feu-a-nouakchott-17-01-2011-1231257.php |title=Mauritanie: mÃ©content du rÃ©gime, un homme s'immole par le feu Ã  Nouakchott |publisher=Le Parisien |date=2011-01-17 |accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref>
There were also similar protests in [[Mauritania]] where Yacoub Ould Dahoud, a protester, [[Self-immolation|burned himself]] near the Presidential Palace in opposition to the policies of [[Mohamed Ould Abdel Aziz]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wikiwix.com/cache/?url=http://www.leparisien.fr/flash-actualite-monde/mauritanie-mecontent-du-regime-un-homme-s-immole-par-le-feu-a-nouakchott-17-01-2011-1231257.php&title=%5B2%5D |title=Wikiwix's cache |publisher=Wikiwix.com |date=2011-01-17 |accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref><!--Is that RS?--><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leparisien.fr/flash-actualite-monde/mauritanie-mecontent-du-regime-un-homme-s-immole-par-le-feu-a-nouakchott-17-01-2011-1231257.php |title=Mauritanie: mÃ©content du rÃ©gime, un homme s'immole par le feu Ã  Nouakchott |publisher=Le Parisien |date=2011-01-17 |accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref>
  +   +
===Morocco===
  +
Inspired by Tunisian and Egyptian protesters, at least four Moroccans have set themselves on fire and on January 30, 2011 at a protest gathering in [[Tangier]].<ref name="afrol1"/><ref>{{cite web|author=February 02, 2011 12:24AM |url=http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/news/opinion/world-waits-for-the-cost-of-democracy/story-e6freabc-1225998405654 |title=World waits for the cost of democracy |publisher=Adelaide Now |date= |accessdate=2011-02-02}}</ref> The Moroccan government and royal family is fearing that mass protests could spread to their nation. Moroccan authorities have okayed an anti-government protest being planned on the popular social networking site Facebook, a media report said. The media report said several Moroccan youth movements have announced on Facebook that they are planning to organise an Egypt-style anti-government protest Feb 20, a move apparently welcomed by the government. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/03/idINIndia-54646220110203 |title=Morocco government plays down call for protests |publisher=Reuters |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://wsws.org/articles/2011/feb2011/moro-f03.shtml |title=Moroccan government fears outbreak of mass protests |publisher=Wsws.org |date=2011-02-03 |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref> Rating agencies Standard & Poor's and Fitch have said the North African country of 32 million people is the least likely in the region to be affected by the wave of popular unrest.
  +   +
===Oman===
  +
In the [[Arab states of the Persian Gulf|Gulf]] country of [[Oman]], 200 protesters marched on 17 January demanding salary increases and lower costs of living. The protest shocked news reporters who have viewed Oman as a "politically stable and sleepy country."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/oman-protestors-call-for-fight-against-corruption--374524.html |title=Oman protestors call for fight against corruption - Culture & Society |publisher=ArabianBusiness.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-29}}</ref>
  +
Meanwhile, the Sultan of Oman cancelled his [[India]] tour because of probably the growing unrest in the Arab world (specially [[Yemen]] which borders [[Oman]]). A week's worth of preparations were called off abruptly and the entourage has now returned back to Oman. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://daily.bhaskar.com/article/RAJ-JOD-entourage-returns-after-omans-sultan-cancels-trip-1827915.html |title=Entourage returns after Oman's Sultan cancels trip |publisher=www.daily.bhaskar.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref>
  +   +
===Saudi Arabia===
  +
In [[Saudi Arabia]], an unidentified 65-year man died on 21 January after setting himself on fire in the town of [[Samtah]], [[Jizan]]. This was apparently the kingdom's first known case of self-immolation.<ref name="saudi">{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12260465|title=Man dies after setting himself on fire in Saudi Arabia|author=|date=23 January 2011 |work=|publisher=BBC News |accessdate=23 January 2011 }}</ref><ref name="saudi2">{{cite web|url=http://sundaytimes.lk/world-news/4231-man-dies-in-possible-first-self-immolation-in-saudi|title=Man dies in possible first self-immolation in Saudi |author=Mohideen Mifthah |date=22 January 2011 |work=|publisher=The Sunday Times, http://sundaytimes.lk/|accessdate=23 January 2011 }}</ref> On 29 January, hundreds of protesters gathered in the city of [[Jeddah]] in a rare display of criticism against the city's poor infrastructure after deadly floods swept through the city, killing eleven people.<ref name="Montreal">{{cite web|url=http://www.montrealgazette.com/news/Flood+sparks+rare+action/4189873/story.html|title=Flood sparks rare action|author=|date=29 January 2011 |work=|publisher=[[The Gazette (Montreal)|Montreal Gazette]] |accessdate=29 January 2011 }}</ref> Police stopped the demonstration about 15 minutes after it started. About 30 to 50 people were arrested.<ref name="Reuters_Dozens_detained">{{cite news | title=Dozens detained in Saudi over flood protests | date=2011-01-29 | publisher=[[The Peninsula]] (Qatar)/[[Thomson-Reuters]] | url=http://www.thepeninsulaqatar.com/middle-east/140720-dozens-detained-in-saudi-over-flood-protests.html |accessdate=2011-01-31 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w9qUZeyR |archivedate=2011-01-31 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
===Sudan===
===Sudan===
Line 131: Line 143:
In late January, the [[African Centre for Justice and Peace Studies]]<ref name="ACJPS_aboutus">{{cite web| last =| first =| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =African Centre for Justice and Peace Studies (About Us)| work =| publisher =[[African Centre for Justice and Peace Studies]] | year =2011| url =http://www.acjps.org/AboutUs.html | doi =| accessdate =2011-02-02 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wCo2PmNW |archivedate=2011-02-02 |deadurl=no }}</ref> reported that more than 100 people had been detained on the first day of protests and that activists were being "taken from their homes and offices".<ref name="defiance2feb" />
In late January, the [[African Centre for Justice and Peace Studies]]<ref name="ACJPS_aboutus">{{cite web| last =| first =| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =African Centre for Justice and Peace Studies (About Us)| work =| publisher =[[African Centre for Justice and Peace Studies]] | year =2011| url =http://www.acjps.org/AboutUs.html | doi =| accessdate =2011-02-02 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wCo2PmNW |archivedate=2011-02-02 |deadurl=no }}</ref> reported that more than 100 people had been detained on the first day of protests and that activists were being "taken from their homes and offices".<ref name="defiance2feb" />
â   â
===Oman===
  â
In the [[Arab states of the Persian Gulf|Gulf]] country of [[Oman]], 200 protesters marched on 17 January demanding salary increases and lower costs of living. The protest shocked news reporters who have viewed Oman as a "politically stable and sleepy country."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/oman-protestors-call-for-fight-against-corruption--374524.html |title=Oman protestors call for fight against corruption - Culture & Society |publisher=ArabianBusiness.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-29}}</ref>
  â
Meanwhile, the Sultan of Oman cancelled his [[India]] tour because of probably the growing unrest in the Arab world (specially [[Yemen]] which borders [[Oman]]). A week's worth of preparations were called off abruptly and the entourage has now returned back to Oman. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://daily.bhaskar.com/article/RAJ-JOD-entourage-returns-after-omans-sultan-cancels-trip-1827915.html |title=Entourage returns after Oman's Sultan cancels trip |publisher=www.daily.bhaskar.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref>
  â   â
===Yemen===
  â
{{main|2011 Yemeni protests}}
  â
Protests occurred in many towns in both the north and south of Yemen starting in mid-January. Protesters initially protested against governmental proposals to modify the [[constitution of Yemen]], unemployment and economic conditions<ref name="afreuters">{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Protests erupt in Yemen, president offers reform | date=2011-01-11 | publisher=Reuters | url=http://af.reuters.com/article/tunisiaNews/idAFLDE70J2BZ20110120?sp=true |accessdate=2011-01-20 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5vt1YRykA |archivedate=2011-01-20 |deadurl=no }}</ref> and corruption.<ref name="People are fed up" /> Their demands increased to calls for President [[Ali Abdullah Saleh]], who has been facing internal opposition from his closest advisors since 2009,<ref name="09SANAA2279">{{cite document| last = Bryan | first =Angie| authorlink =| coauthors =| title = Yemeni tribal leader: for Saleh, Saudi involvement in Sa'ada comes not a moment too soon | id={{WikiLeaks cable|09SANAA2279}} |work =| publisher =[[WikiLeaks]]| date =2009-12-28| url =http://wikileaks.ch/cable/2009/12/09SANAA2279.html |format =| doi =| accessdate =2011-01-31 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w8OrQ284 |archivedate=2011-01-31 |deadurl=no }}</ref> to resign.<ref name="NADA BAKRI" >{{cite news | last= BAKRI | first= NADA | url= http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/28/world/middleeast/28yemen.html | title= Thousands in Yemen Protest Against the Government | publisher= The New York Times | date= 27 Jan 2011 | accessdate= }}</ref><ref name="People are fed up">{{cite news | url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12298019 | title= Yemen protests: 'People are fed up with corruption' | publisher= BBC News | date= 27 January 2011 | accessdate= }}</ref><ref name="urge leader">{{cite news | url= http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112314714887766.html | title= Yemen protests urge leader's exit | publisher= [[Aljazeera]] | date= 23 Jan 2011 | accessdate= }}</ref> A major demonstration of over 16,000 protestors took place in [[Sana'a]] on 27 January<ref name="Irish Times breaking26">{{cite news | url= http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2011/0127/breaking26.html| title= Yemenis in anti-president protest| publisher= [[Irish Times]]| date= January 27, 2011| accessdate= }}</ref> and [[human rights in Yemen|human rights activist]] and politician [[Tawakel Karman]] called for a "Day of Rage" on 3 February.<ref name="Feb3_DayRage_aljaz" >{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=New protests erupt in Yemen | date=2011-01-29 | publisher=[[Al Jazeera]] | url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/2011129112626339573.html |accessdate=2011-01-30 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w8S9MZ1r |archivedate=2011-01-30 |deadurl=no }}</ref> A million protesters were expected, but only 20 thousand showed up.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2011-02/02/c_13716611.htm |title=Yemen reinforces forces around capital amid fear of protest escalation |date=2011-02-02 |accessdate=2011-02-02}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12353479|title=Yemen protests: 20,000 call for President Saleh to go}}</ref> As a preemptive response to these protests, Ali Abdullah Saleh will not seek another presidential term.<ref>{{cite web|last=Sudam |first=Mohamed |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/02/us-yemen-president-idUSTRE7111WC20110202 |title=Yemeni president signals he won't stay beyond 2013 |publisher=Reuters |date= |accessdate=2011-02-02}}</ref>
  â   â
===Saudi Arabia===
  â
In [[Saudi Arabia]], an unidentified 65-year man died on 21 January after setting himself on fire in the town of [[Samtah]], [[Jizan]]. This was apparently the kingdom's first known case of self-immolation.<ref name="saudi">{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12260465|title=Man dies after setting himself on fire in Saudi Arabia|author=|date=23 January 2011 |work=|publisher=BBC News |accessdate=23 January 2011 }}</ref><ref name="saudi2">{{cite web|url=http://sundaytimes.lk/world-news/4231-man-dies-in-possible-first-self-immolation-in-saudi|title=Man dies in possible first self-immolation in Saudi |author=Mohideen Mifthah |date=22 January 2011 |work=|publisher=The Sunday Times, http://sundaytimes.lk/|accessdate=23 January 2011 }}</ref> On 29 January, hundreds of protesters gathered in the city of [[Jeddah]] in a rare display of criticism against the city's poor infrastructure after deadly floods swept through the city, killing eleven people.<ref name="Montreal">{{cite web|url=http://www.montrealgazette.com/news/Flood+sparks+rare+action/4189873/story.html|title=Flood sparks rare action|author=|date=29 January 2011 |work=|publisher=[[The Gazette (Montreal)|Montreal Gazette]] |accessdate=29 January 2011 }}</ref> Police stopped the demonstration about 15 minutes after it started. About 30 to 50 people were arrested.<ref name="Reuters_Dozens_detained">{{cite news | title=Dozens detained in Saudi over flood protests | date=2011-01-29 | publisher=[[The Peninsula]] (Qatar)/[[Thomson-Reuters]] | url=http://www.thepeninsulaqatar.com/middle-east/140720-dozens-detained-in-saudi-over-flood-protests.html |accessdate=2011-01-31 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w9qUZeyR |archivedate=2011-01-31 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
  â   â
===Egypt===
  â
{{Incomplete|date=February 2011}}<!--need roots of conflict instead of extraneous details like the stock market-->
  â
[[File:Day of Anger marchers with out signs.jpg|thumb|Protesters marching on 25 January. Demonstrators later moved to [[Midan Tahrir|al-Tahrir Square]], in [[Downtown Cairo]], where the main protests were being held.]]
  â
{{main|2011 Egyptian protests}}
  â   â
Following the [[Death of Khaled Mohamed Saeed|death of Khaled Saeed]] in June of 2010, and the later uprising in Tunisia, potential [[Egyptian presidential election, 2011|presidential candidate]] [[Mohamed ElBaradei]] warned of a "Tunisia-style explosion" in the country.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theage.com.au/world/warning-egypt-could-follow-tunisia-20110119-19wly.html|title=Warning Egypt could follow Tunisia|author=Jack Shenker}}</ref>
  â   â
Starting at about 00:10 to 00:35 on 28 January (Egypt time), in an unprecedented action in the history of [[Internet censorship]], the Egyptian government almost entirely cut off Egypt from the rest of the Internet.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pomed.org/blog/2011/01/egypt-ap-confirms-government-has-disrupted-internet-service.html/ |title=Egypt: AP Confirms Government has Disrupted Internet Service |publisher=pomed.org |date= |accessdate=2011-01-28}}</ref>
  â   â
Later that day, as tens of thousand protested on the streets of Egypt's major cities, President Mubarak formally fired his government, and appointed a new one, which included the first Vice President in almost 30 years.
  â   â
However, this did not mollify anyone, and over the next few days the crowds grew, with some estimates in the hundreds of thousands. According to Al Jazeera on 1 February at least one million protesters gathered on Tahrir Square and adjacent streets.<ref>{{cite web |publisher=Al Jazeera News|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/2011215827193882.html|title=Protesters flood Egypt streets|date=1 February 2011|accessdate=2011-01-31}}</ref> President Mubarak subsequently proclaimed that he will not contend for another presidential term.
  â   â
Beginning on 2 February, armed men on camels and horses began to attack protesters with [[Molotov cocktails]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20110202/ap_on_re_mi_ea/ml_egypt |title=Mubarak backers attack anti-government protesters - Yahoo! News |publisher=News.yahoo.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-02}}</ref>
  â   â
The same organisers of the "Day of Anger" and "Friday of Anger" called for a protest in front of the presidential [[Heliopolis Palace]] on 4 February, which was dubbed the "'''Friday of Departure'''".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/163162.html|title=4 Feb. Declared the 'Friday of Departure'|author=|date=2 February 2011|work=[[Press TV]]|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> ({{lang-ar|Ø¬ÙØ¹Ø© Ø§ÙØ±Ø­ÙÙ}} ''{{transl|ar|DIN|gumÊ¿at ar-raá¸¥Ä«l}}'')<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alraimedia.com/Alrai/Article.aspx?id=253982&date=02022011|title=Ø¬ÙØ¹Ø© Ø§ÙØ±Ø­ÙÙ|language=[[Arabic language|Arabic]]|author=|date=2 February 2011|work=[[Al Rai]]|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> They demanded Mubarak step down immediately, with 4 February their deadline for him to surrender his powers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Egypt-Protests-What-Will-Be-The-Future-For-President-Mubarak/Article/201102115920698?lpos=World_News_First_World_News_Article_Teaser_Region_4&lid=ARTICLE_15920698_Egypt_Protests%3A_What_Will_Be_The_Future_For_President_Mubarak|title=What Is the Future for President Mubarak?|author=|date=2 February 2011|work=[[Sky News]]|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
 
===Syria===
===Syria===
Line 169: Line 153:
The protests were expected to begin on February 4, 2011 as [[social media]] mobilised the people of [[Syria]] for rallies demanding freedom, [[human rights]] and the end to the [[emergency law]]. Protests were also scheduled for 5 February in front of the parliament in [[Damascus]] and at Syrian embassies internationally.<ref>[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201122171649677912.html "Calls for weekend protests in Syria"].</ref> The planned protests had been named "Day of Rage."<ref>[http://www.aolnews.com/2011/01/31/syria-protests-set-for-feb-5-will-the-day-of-rage-mirror-eg/ AOL News].</ref> President [[Bashar al-Assad]] has declared that his state is immune from the kinds of mass protests taking place in Egypt.<ref>[http://www.foxnews.com/opinion/2011/02/02/middle-east-protests-syria-egypt/ FOX News opinion].</ref> ''Al Jazeera'' also reported plans to increase security for the planned "days of rage." However, no protests occurred on either date. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/Special/2011/02/04/Syria-quiet-on-day-of-rage/UPI-58781296853501/ |title=Syria quiet on day of rage |publisher=UPI.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/world/2011/0205/1224289070429.html |title=Call for Syrian 'day of rage' as planned protests fail to ignite - The Irish Times - Sat, Feb 05, 2011 |publisher=The Irish Times |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Karam |first=Zeina |url=http://www.miamiherald.com/2011/02/05/2052033/syria-escapes-day-of-rage-protests.html |title=Syria escapes 'Day of Rage' protests - World Wires |publisher=MiamiHerald.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref>
The protests were expected to begin on February 4, 2011 as [[social media]] mobilised the people of [[Syria]] for rallies demanding freedom, [[human rights]] and the end to the [[emergency law]]. Protests were also scheduled for 5 February in front of the parliament in [[Damascus]] and at Syrian embassies internationally.<ref>[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201122171649677912.html "Calls for weekend protests in Syria"].</ref> The planned protests had been named "Day of Rage."<ref>[http://www.aolnews.com/2011/01/31/syria-protests-set-for-feb-5-will-the-day-of-rage-mirror-eg/ AOL News].</ref> President [[Bashar al-Assad]] has declared that his state is immune from the kinds of mass protests taking place in Egypt.<ref>[http://www.foxnews.com/opinion/2011/02/02/middle-east-protests-syria-egypt/ FOX News opinion].</ref> ''Al Jazeera'' also reported plans to increase security for the planned "days of rage." However, no protests occurred on either date. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/Special/2011/02/04/Syria-quiet-on-day-of-rage/UPI-58781296853501/ |title=Syria quiet on day of rage |publisher=UPI.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/world/2011/0205/1224289070429.html |title=Call for Syrian 'day of rage' as planned protests fail to ignite - The Irish Times - Sat, Feb 05, 2011 |publisher=The Irish Times |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Karam |first=Zeina |url=http://www.miamiherald.com/2011/02/05/2052033/syria-escapes-day-of-rage-protests.html |title=Syria escapes 'Day of Rage' protests - World Wires |publisher=MiamiHerald.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref>
â
===Morocco===
+
===Tunisia===
â
Inspired by Tunisian and Egyptian protesters, at least four Moroccans have set themselves on fire and on January 30, 2011 at a protest gathering in [[Tangier]].<ref name="afrol1"/><ref>{{cite web|author=February 02, 2011 12:24AM |url=http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/news/opinion/world-waits-for-the-cost-of-democracy/story-e6freabc-1225998405654 |title=World waits for the cost of democracy |publisher=Adelaide Now |date= |accessdate=2011-02-02}}</ref> The Moroccan government and royal family is fearing that mass protests could spread to their nation. Moroccan authorities have okayed an anti-government protest being planned on the popular social networking site Facebook, a media report said. The media report said several Moroccan youth movements have announced on Facebook that they are planning to organise an Egypt-style anti-government protest Feb 20, a move apparently welcomed by the government. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/03/idINIndia-54646220110203 |title=Morocco government plays down call for protests |publisher=Reuters |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://wsws.org/articles/2011/feb2011/moro-f03.shtml |title=Moroccan government fears outbreak of mass protests |publisher=Wsws.org |date=2011-02-03 |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref> Rating agencies Standard & Poor's and Fitch have said the North African country of 32 million people is the least likely in the region to be affected by the wave of popular unrest.
+
[[File:Tunisia Unrest - VOA - Tunis 14 Jan 2011 (2).jpg|thumb|Demonstrators in downtown [[Tunis]] on January 14th, 2011]]
  +
{{main|2010â2011 Tunisian uprising}}
  +
The 2010â2011 Tunisian uprising is a continuing series of street demonstrations taking place throughout Tunisia from December 2010 onwards. The demonstrations and riots were reported to have started over unemployment, food inflation, corruption, freedom of speech and poor living conditions. The protests were exacerbated by the self-immolation of [[Mohamed Bouazizi]] that eventually led to the ousting of President Zine El Abidine Ben Ali, who stepped down from the presidency and fled Tunisia on 14 January 2011 after 23 years in power.
â
===Djibouti===
+
===Yemen===
â
Three-hundred people protested against President [[Ismail Omar Guelleh]] in [[Djibouti (city)|Djibouti]] asking him not to run for another term and also for more liberty and for political and social reform. ''[[Somalilandpress]]'' described the protests as peaceful.<ref>{{cite news|title=People in Djibouti protest against President Gelleh|author=|newspaper=Somalilandpress|date=|url=http://somalilandpress.com/people-in-djibouti-protest-againts-president-gelleh-19925|accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref>
+
{{main|2011 Yemeni protests}}
â
+
Protests occurred in many towns in both the north and south of Yemen starting in mid-January. Protesters initially protested against governmental proposals to modify the [[constitution of Yemen]], unemployment and economic conditions<ref name="afreuters">{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=Protests erupt in Yemen, president offers reform | date=2011-01-11 | publisher=Reuters | url=http://af.reuters.com/article/tunisiaNews/idAFLDE70J2BZ20110120?sp=true |accessdate=2011-01-20 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5vt1YRykA |archivedate=2011-01-20 |deadurl=no }}</ref> and corruption.<ref name="People are fed up" /> Their demands increased to calls for President [[Ali Abdullah Saleh]], who has been facing internal opposition from his closest advisors since 2009,<ref name="09SANAA2279">{{cite document| last = Bryan | first =Angie| authorlink =| coauthors =| title = Yemeni tribal leader: for Saleh, Saudi involvement in Sa'ada comes not a moment too soon | id={{WikiLeaks cable|09SANAA2279}} |work =| publisher =[[WikiLeaks]]| date =2009-12-28| url =http://wikileaks.ch/cable/2009/12/09SANAA2279.html |format =| doi =| accessdate =2011-01-31 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w8OrQ284 |archivedate=2011-01-31 |deadurl=no }}</ref> to resign.<ref name="NADA BAKRI" >{{cite news | last= BAKRI | first= NADA | url= http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/28/world/middleeast/28yemen.html | title= Thousands in Yemen Protest Against the Government | publisher= The New York Times | date= 27 Jan 2011 | accessdate= }}</ref><ref name="People are fed up">{{cite news | url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12298019 | title= Yemen protests: 'People are fed up with corruption' | publisher= BBC News | date= 27 January 2011 | accessdate= }}</ref><ref name="urge leader">{{cite news | url= http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112314714887766.html | title= Yemen protests urge leader's exit | publisher= [[Aljazeera]] | date= 23 Jan 2011 | accessdate= }}</ref> A major demonstration of over 16,000 protestors took place in [[Sana'a]] on 27 January<ref name="Irish Times breaking26">{{cite news | url= http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2011/0127/breaking26.html| title= Yemenis in anti-president protest| publisher= [[Irish Times]]| date= January 27, 2011| accessdate= }}</ref> and [[human rights in Yemen|human rights activist]] and politician [[Tawakel Karman]] called for a "Day of Rage" on 3 February.<ref name="Feb3_DayRage_aljaz" >{{cite news | first= | last= | pages= | language =| title=New protests erupt in Yemen | date=2011-01-29 | publisher=[[Al Jazeera]] | url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/2011129112626339573.html |accessdate=2011-01-30 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w8S9MZ1r |archivedate=2011-01-30 |deadurl=no }}</ref> A million protesters were expected, but only 20 thousand showed up.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2011-02/02/c_13716611.htm |title=Yemen reinforces forces around capital amid fear of protest escalation |date=2011-02-02 |accessdate=2011-02-02}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12353479|title=Yemen protests: 20,000 call for President Saleh to go}}</ref> As a preemptive response to these protests, Ali Abdullah Saleh will not seek another presidential term.<ref>{{cite web|last=Sudam |first=Mohamed |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/02/us-yemen-president-idUSTRE7111WC20110202 |title=Yemeni president signals he won't stay beyond 2013 |publisher=Reuters |date= |accessdate=2011-02-02}}</ref>
â
===Bahrain===
  â
''Al Jazeera'' reported planned protests in the country{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}}, which follow just months on from a controversial [[Bahraini parliamentary election, 2010|election]]. On 4 February, several hundred Bahrainis gathered in front of the Egyptian embassy in [[Manama]] to express solidarity with anti-government protesters in Egypt.<ref name="WSJ_bahrain_20110204">{{cite news | first= Nour | last= Malas |coauthors= Hassan Hafidh, Joel Millman | pages= | language =| title=Protests Emerge in Jordan, Bahrain | date=2011-02-05 | publisher=Wall Street Journal | url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748704709304576124623383327338.html |accessdate=2011-02-06 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wKLMmSyY |archivedate=2011-02-07 |deadurl=no }}</ref> According to the ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', this was "one of the first such gatherings to be held in the oil-rich Persian Gulf states."<ref name="WSJ_bahrain_20110204" /> At the gathering, [[Ibrahim Sharif]], the secretary-general of the [[National Democratic Action Society]], (al-Wa'ad) called for "local reform."<ref name="WSJ_bahrain_20110204" />
  â   â
Bahraini youth also called for Bahrainis "to take to the streets on Monday 14 February in a peaceful and orderly manner" in order to rewrite the [[Constitution of Bahrain|constitution]] and to establish a body with a "full popular mandate to investigate and hold to account [[human rights in Bahrain|economic, political and social violations]], including stolen public wealth, political naturalisation, arrests, [[torture in Bahrain|torture]] and other oppressive security measures, [and] institutional and economic corruption."<ref name="bahrainonline_20110214">{{cite web| last =| first =| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =A statement by Bahraini Youth for Freedom published on BahrainOnline | work =| publisher =BahrainOnline| date =2011| url =http://bahrainonline.info.tm/ |format =| doi =| accessdate =2011-02-07 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5wKQYGf0Q |archivedate=2011-02-07 |deadurl=no }}</ref><ref name="aljaz_febdominos" /> They referred to the uprisings in Tunisia and Egypt as motivations for their appeal.<ref name="bahrainonline_20110214" />
